name: Claude Code
tagline: Let Claude Code handle your revenue ops while you ship product
description: Claude Code is Anthropic's agentic coding tool that lives in your terminal. Connect it to Beton via MCP and it can check signals, score leads, and route revenue data — all from natural language prompts while you code.

steps: Install Claude Code: `npm install -g @anthropic-ai/claude-code`
Add Beton MCP config to `~/.claude/claude_desktop_config.json`
Set your `BETON_API_KEY` in the config
Restart Claude Code — Beton tools are now available

examplePrompts.prompt: Check if there are any new high-confidence signals today
examplePrompts.description: Lists recent signals detected by Beton, filtered by confidence score

examplePrompts.prompt: Score the leads from acme.com and route to HubSpot if qualified
examplePrompts.description: Runs lead scoring and conditionally routes the signal to your CRM

examplePrompts.prompt: Analyze the account activity for widget-corp.io this week
examplePrompts.description: Pulls account-level behavioral data and summarizes key patterns

examplePrompts.prompt: Route all PQL signals above 0.8 confidence to the sales team channel
examplePrompts.description: Batch-routes high-quality product-qualified leads to a destination

capabilities: Detect revenue signals from product usage data
Score and qualify leads in real time
Route signals to CRMs, Slack, or webhooks
Analyze account-level behavioral patterns
List and filter signals by type, confidence, or date

workflows.title: Morning Signal Review
workflows.description: Start your day by asking Claude Code to check overnight signals. It pulls the latest from Beton, summarizes the high-priority ones, and can route them before your first meeting.

workflows.title: Sprint-End Account Health
workflows.description: At the end of a sprint, ask Claude Code to analyze account activity across your top accounts. Spot expansion opportunities or churn risks without leaving your terminal.

workflows.title: Automated Lead Routing
workflows.description: Set up a workflow where Claude Code periodically checks for new PQLs and routes them to HubSpot or Attio with context — signal type, confidence score, and triggering events.

faq.question: Does Beton replace Claude Code?
faq.answer: No. Beton is a revenue intelligence tool, and Claude Code is a coding agent. They work together — Claude Code calls Beton's MCP tools to handle revenue ops tasks like signal detection and lead routing.

faq.question: Do I need a paid Beton plan to use this?
faq.answer: You can self-host Beton for free and connect it via MCP. Cloud plans start at $0.50/tracked user/month for managed hosting.

faq.question: What MCP tools does Beton expose?
faq.answer: Beton exposes five MCP tools: `beton_check_signals` (detect new signals), `beton_score_leads` (score and qualify), `beton_route_signal` (send to destinations), `beton_analyze_account` (behavioral analysis), and `beton_list_signals` (query signal history).

faq.question: Can Claude Code trigger actions in my CRM through Beton?
faq.answer: Yes. When Claude Code calls `beton_route_signal`, Beton delivers the signal to your configured destinations — HubSpot, Attio, Pipedrive, webhooks, or any connected integration.

seo.metaTitle: Beton + Claude Code: MCP Revenue Intelligence
seo.metaDescription: Connect Beton to Claude Code via MCP. Detect revenue signals, score leads, and route to your CRM — all from natural language prompts in your terminal.

faq.question: Is this different from using Beton's web dashboard?
faq.answer: The data is the same. The difference is workflow — instead of switching to a dashboard, you interact with Beton through natural language in your editor. Faster for developers who live in their IDE.

faq.question: Can I use Beton with Cursor's free plan?
faq.answer: MCP support is available in Cursor Pro and above. Beton itself can be self-hosted for free.

faq.question: What happens if my Beton instance is self-hosted?
faq.answer: The MCP server connects to whatever Beton instance you configure — cloud or self-hosted. Just point the BETON_API_KEY to your instance.

faq.question: Is Gemini CLI free to use with Beton?
faq.answer: Gemini CLI is open-source and free. Beton can be self-hosted for free as well. You only need API keys for both services.

faq.question: Does this work with Google Cloud's Gemini API?
faq.answer: Gemini CLI uses Google's Gemini models. Beton connects as an MCP tool server — the AI model doesn't matter, only the MCP protocol support.

faq.question: Can Gemini CLI access all of Beton's MCP tools?
faq.answer: Yes. All five Beton MCP tools (`beton_check_signals`, `beton_score_leads`, `beton_route_signal`, `beton_analyze_account`, `beton_list_signals`) are available through Gemini CLI's MCP integration.

faq.question: How is this different from using Beton's API directly?
faq.answer: MCP adds a natural language layer. Instead of writing API calls, you describe what you want in plain English and Gemini figures out which Beton tools to call and how to chain them.

faq.question: Why use Beton with OpenClaw instead of building signal detection from scratch?
faq.answer: Beton provides a battle-tested signal detection engine with pre-built CRM integrations. OpenClaw provides the orchestration layer. Together, you get production-ready revenue ops without building the detection logic yourself.

faq.question: Can I use Beton alongside other MCP tools in OpenClaw?
faq.answer: Yes, that's the main benefit. OpenClaw's agent pipelines can call multiple MCP servers. Chain Beton with enrichment tools, notification tools, or any other MCP-compatible service.

faq.question: Does OpenClaw support Beton's self-hosted deployment?
faq.answer: Yes. The MCP server connects to any Beton instance. Point your config to your self-hosted URL and API key.

faq.question: Is there a performance overhead from using MCP vs direct API calls?
faq.answer: MCP adds minimal overhead — it's a thin protocol layer over stdio. For revenue ops workflows that run on minute-level schedules, the difference is negligible.

faq.question: Is Beton's MCP server compatible with Cline's tool format?
